message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest rheumatoid arthritis, which is characterized by proliferation of granulation tissue in the synovial membrane. Monosodium urate and calcium pyrophosphate crystals are associated with gout and pseudogout, respectively. Noncaseating granulomas are associated with sarcoidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest rheumatoid arthritis, which is characterized by proliferation of granulation tissue in the synovium. Monosodium urate crystals are associated with gout, calcium pyrophosphate crystals with pseudogout, and noncaseating granulomas with sarcoidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and x-ray findings suggest rheumatoid arthritis. Synovial biopsy from an affected joint in rheumatoid arthritis would most likely show proliferation of granulation tissue. Monosodium urate crystals are associated with gout, not rheumatoid arthritis. Calcium pyrophosphate crystals are associated with pseudogout. Noncaseating granulomas are associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest rheumatoid arthritis, which is characterized by proliferation of granulation tissue in the synovium. Monosodium urate and calcium pyrophosphate crystals are associated with gout and pseudogout respectively, and noncaseating granulomas are seen in conditions such as sarcoidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The x-ray shows joint destruction which is seen in rheumatoid arthritis. Synovial biopsy from an affected joint in rheumatoid arthritis would show proliferation of granulation tissue. Monosodium urate crystals are seen in gout, calcium pyrophosphate crystals are seen in pseudogout, and noncaseating granulomas are seen in sarcoidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This patient is most likely suffering from rheumatoid arthritis based on the symptoms and findings. Synovial biopsy would show proliferation of granulation tissue, which is a hallmark of rheumatoid arthritis. Monosodium urate crystals would be seen in gout, calcium pyrophosphate crystals in pseudogout, and noncaseating granulomas in sarcoidosis.

Monosodium urate crystals are found in gout, calcium pyrophosphate crystals are found in pseudogout, and noncaseating granulomas are found in sarcoidosis.

Proliferation of granulation tissue is the most likely finding on synovial biopsy. Monosodium urate crystals are seen in gout, calcium pyrophosphate crystals are seen in pseudogout, and noncaseating granulomas are seen in sarcoidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The x-ray shows erosions and joint space narrowing, which suggest proliferative synovitis. Among the options, the most likely finding in synovial biopsy would be proliferation of granulation tissue. Monosodium urate crystals are found in gout, calcium pyrophosphate crystals are found in pseudogout, and noncaseating granulomas are found in sarcoidosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest rheumatoid arthritis which is associated with proliferation of granulation tissue in synovial membranes. Monosodium urate and calcium pyrophosphate crystals are seen in gout and calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease, respectively. Noncaseating granulomas are characteristic of sarcoidosis.
